content: Recognize the signs of mania. During a manic period, feelings of euphoria, creativity, and heightened awareness are common. [4] Manic periods may last a few hours or stretch on for days or weeks. [5] The Mayo Clinic describes the following signs of mania: [6] Having a feeling of being "high," so high, in some cases, that one feels invincible. This is often accompanied by the feeling that one has special powers or is godlike. Dealing with racing thoughts. Thoughts may jump from subject to subject so quickly that it's difficult to keep up or concentrate on one thing. Talking so quickly that others can't make sense of what one is saying, and feeling jumpy and restless. Staying up all night or sleeping for only a few hours at a time, but never feeling tired the next day. Exhibiting reckless behavior. During a manic episode, a person might sleep with several people and not use protection. He or she may gamble large amounts of money or make risky business investments. An individual might also spend money on large, expensive items, quit a job, and so on. Exhibiting extreme irritability and impatience with others. This can escalate into starting arguments and picking fights with people who don't go along with one's ideas. In rare cases, delusions, hallucinations, and visions can occur (e.g. believing to hear the voice of God or an angel). Know the symptoms of bipolar depression. For those with bipolar disorder, the periods of depression are longer and more frequent than periods of mania. Watch for these symptoms: [7] An inability to experience pleasure, joy even happiness. Feelings of hopelessness and inadequacy. Feelings of worthlessness and guilt are also common. Sleeping more than normal and feeling tired and sluggish all the time. Gaining weight and having changes in appetite. Experiencing thoughts of death and suicide. Note that bipolar depression often looks a lot like Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). A qualified professional can differentiate between the two disorders. He or she will look at the patient’s history of mania and severity of manic episodes. [8] The medication used to treat MDD is often not effective for treating bipolar depression. It also is often accompanied by irritability and mood swings that aren't exhibited by those with MDD. [9] Understand the signs of a Hypomanic Episode. A Hypomanic Episode is an abnormally and persistently elevated mood that lasts for four days. It can also include irritability and other symptoms. [10] Hypomania is different from a manic episode because it is usually less severe. Watch out for: [11] Feelings of Elation Irritability Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity Decreased need for sleep Pressured speech (speech that is rapid and intense) Flight of ideas (when one’s brain seems to move rapidly from one idea to another) Distractibility Psychomotor agitation, such as bouncing your leg or tapping your fingers, or an inability to sit still With hypomania, an individual may not have problems in their social or work life. This condition typically does not result in hospitalization. Someone experiencing Hypomania might feel elated, and have an increased appetite or sex drive. But, he or she would likely still be able to go to work and manage ordinary tasks without many, if any, negative consequences. Someone in a Hypomanic episode can usually complete work tasks. He or she should also have appropriate (though perhaps intense) interactions with coworkers. With full mania, regular tasks at work would be difficult to complete without making errors in judgment. Likewise, inappropriate social interactions might lead to negative consequences. Delusions and hallucinations are also not present in Hypomania. [12] Understand mixed features. In some cases, people experience mania and depression at the same time. These individuals experience depression and irritability, racing thoughts, anxiety, and insomnia simultaneously. Mania and Hypomania can qualify as having mixed features if there are also three or more symptoms of depression. For example, imagine someone is engaging in risky behaviors. He or she is also experiencing insomnia, hyperactivity, and racing thoughts. This satisfies the full criteria for mania. If this person also experiences at least three symptoms of depression, this is a manic episode with mixed features. Example might be feelings of worthlessness, loss of interest in hobbies or activities, and recurrent thoughts of death. [13] Know the characteristics of bipolar disorder. This form of bipolar disorder is the most commonly known manic-depressive form of the illness. A person classified as bipolar I must experience at least one manic episode or mixed episode. People with bipolar I disorder may also experience a depressive episode. [14] People with bipolar I are the most likely to experience highs that lead to risky behavior. This form of the illness is often disruptive to one's work life and relationships. Those affected by Bipolar I are more likely to attempt suicide, with a completed suicide rate of 10-15%. [15] People suffering from bipolar I are also at a high risk of having or developing a substance abuse problem. [16] There is also a connection between bipolar I and hyperthyroidism. This makes it even more important to see a doctor. [17] Understand the symptoms of bipolar II disorder. This variation involves less intense manic episodes and full-blown depressive episodes. The person may sometimes experience a muted version of hypomania. But, the underlying state is usually depression. [18] People with bipolar II disorder are often misdiagnosed as having depression. To tell the difference, one must look for the distinguishing characteristics of bipolar depression. Bipolar depression is different from MDD because it is often paired with manic symptoms. Sometimes there is overlap between the two. It takes a qualified professional to distinguish between these conditions. [19] For people with bipolar II, mania may manifest as anxiety, irritability, or racing thoughts. Bursts of creativity and activity are less common. Like bipolar I, there is a high risk for suicide, hyperthyroidism, and substance abuse in bipolar II. [20] Bipolar II tends to be more common in women than men. [21] Look for the signs of cyclothymia. This is a milder form of bipolar disorder that involves mood swings with less severe instances of mania and depression. The mood swings tend to operate on a cycle, going back and forth between depression and mania. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM): [22] Cyclothymia begins early in life and it’s onset is usually in adolescence and early adulthood. Cyclothymia is equally common in men and women. As with bipolar I and II, there is an increased risk of substance abuse for those affected by cyclothymia. Sleep disorders are also commonly found alongside cyclothymia. Look for seasonal changes in mood. It's common for people with bipolar disorder to experience a shift as the seasons change. In some cases, a manic or depressive episode will last an entire season. In other cases, the change in season prompts the beginning of a cycle that includes both mania and depression. Manic episodes are more common in the summertime. Depressive episodes are more common in the fall, winter and spring. This is not a hard and fast rule, however; some people experience depression in the summer and mania in the winter. [23] Understand that having bipolar disorder doesn't always impair functionality. Some people with bipolar disorder have trouble at work and in school. In other cases, the person may seem to be doing just fine in these areas. Those with bipolar II and cyclothymia can often function at work and school. Those with bipolar I tend to have a harder time in these areas. [24] Be aware of substance abuse issues. Up to 50 percent of people who suffer from bipolar disorder struggle with substance abuse. They use alcohol or other tranquilizers to stop racing thoughts during manic episodes. They may also use drugs to try to achieve a high when they're in a depressive episode. [25] Substances like alcohol have their own effects on mood and behavior. They can be difficult to distinguish bipolar disorder. People who abuse drugs and alcohol are at greater risk of suicide. This is because substance abuse can increase the severity of both mania and depression. Substance abuse may also instigate a cycle of manic depression. Notice breaks from reality. People with bipolar disorder are often out of touch with reality. This occurs both during periods of extreme mania and periods of severe depression. This can manifest as either a dangerously inflated ego or a sense of guilt that is not in proportion to real events. In some cases, psychosis and hallucinations occur. Breaks from reality happen most frequently in bipolar I during manic and mixed episodes. They occur less often in bipolar II and almost never in cyclothymia. [26] See a specialist. Self-diagnosis is useful if it leads to taking the next step toward getting help. Many people live with bipolar disorder without receiving treatment. But, the illness can be better managed with helpful medications. Psychotherapy with a psychiatrist or counselor can also make a big difference. Medications used to treat Bipolar Disorder include mood stabilizers, anti-depressants, anti-psychotic, and anti-anxiety drugs. These medications work by blocking and/or regulating certain chemicals in the brain. They regulate Dopamine, Serotonin, and Acetylcholine. [27] Mood stabilizers work to regulate a person’s mood. They prevent the extreme highs and lows of bipolar disorder. Among these are drugs such as Lithium, Depakote, Neurontin, Lamictal, and Topamax. [28] Antipsychotic medications help reduce psychotic symptoms like hallucinations or delusions during mania. They include Zyprexa, Risperdal, Abilify and Saphris. [29] Anti-depressant medications used to treat Bipolar depression include Lexapro, Zoloft, Prozac, and others. Finally, to manage symptoms of anxiety, a psychiatrist might prescribe Xanax, Klonopin, or Lorazepam. [30] Medications should always be prescribed by a qualified psychiatrist or physician. They should be taken as directed to avoid health complications. If you're concerned that you or a loved one has bipolar disorder, reach out to a therapist or psychiatrist for diagnosis. If you or a loved one is having suicidal thoughts, immediately contact a trusted loved one or friend. Call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-8255 for more advice. [31]

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder">How to Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Trudi Griffin, LPC</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Identifying_the_Symptoms_sub" id="">Identifying the Symptoms</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Understanding_Different_Forms_of_Bipolar_Disorder_sub" id="">Understanding Different Forms of Bipolar Disorder</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Know_How_to_Spot_Bipolar_Disorder_sub" id="">Know How to Spot Bipolar Disorder</a>
<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=trudigriffin%2Clpc#trudigriffin%2Clpc">Trudi Griffin, LPC</a>. Trudi Griffin is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Wisconsin. She received her MS in Clinical Mental Health Counseling from Marquette University in 2011.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">31 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Bipolar disorder is a type of mood disorder affecting somewhere between one and 4.3 percent of the US population.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> It commonly manifests in periods of elevated mood known as mania. These manic episodes alternate with a depressed mood. Bipolar disorder often has an early onset. Research has shown that 1.8% of children and adolescents merit a Bipolar diagnosis.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> Typically though, the disorder is diagnosed around the late twenties or early thirties.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> This article will help you determine whether you, or people you care about, might have bipolar disorder.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Identifying_the_Symptoms_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Identifying_the_Symptoms">Identifying the Symptoms</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_2f5b1903c6" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2f5b1903c6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Recognize the signs of mania.</b> During a manic period, feelings of euphoria, creativity, and heightened awareness are common.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup> Manic periods may last a few hours or stretch on for days or weeks.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> The Mayo Clinic describes the following signs of mania:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Having a feeling of being "high," so high, in some cases, that one feels invincible. This is often accompanied by the feeling that one has special powers or is godlike.</li>
<li>Dealing with racing thoughts. Thoughts may jump from subject to subject so quickly that it's difficult to keep up or concentrate on one thing.</li>
<li>Talking so quickly that others can't make sense of what one is saying, and feeling jumpy and restless.</li>
<li>Staying up all night or sleeping for only a few hours at a time, but never feeling tired the next day.</li>
<li>Exhibiting reckless behavior. During a manic episode, a person might sleep with several people and not use protection. He or she may gamble large amounts of money or make risky business investments. An individual might also spend money on large, expensive items, quit a job, and so on.</li>
<li>Exhibiting extreme irritability and impatience with others. This can escalate into starting arguments and picking fights with people who don't go along with one's ideas.</li>
<li>In rare cases, delusions, hallucinations, and visions can occur (e.g. believing to hear the voice of God or an angel).</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_73e6ef81f4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_73e6ef81f4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know the symptoms of bipolar depression.</b> For those with bipolar disorder, the periods of depression are longer and more frequent than periods of mania. Watch for these symptoms:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>An inability to experience pleasure, joy even happiness.</li>
<li>Feelings of hopelessness and inadequacy. Feelings of worthlessness and guilt are also common.</li>
<li>Sleeping more than normal and feeling tired and sluggish all the time.</li>
<li>Gaining weight and having changes in appetite.</li>
<li>Experiencing thoughts of death and suicide.</li>
<li>Note that bipolar depression often looks a lot like Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). A qualified professional can differentiate between the two disorders. He or she will look at the patient’s history of mania and severity of manic episodes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>The medication used to treat MDD is often not effective for treating bipolar depression. It also is often accompanied by irritability and mood swings that aren't exhibited by those with MDD.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_84503a6dc9" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_84503a6dc9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand the signs of a Hypomanic Episode.</b> A Hypomanic Episode is an abnormally and persistently elevated mood that lasts for four days. It can also include irritability and other symptoms.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>Hypomania is different from a manic episode because it is usually less severe. Watch out for:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Feelings of Elation</li>
<li>Irritability</li>
<li>Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity</li>
<li>Decreased need for sleep</li>
<li>Pressured speech (speech that is rapid and intense)</li>
<li>Flight of ideas (when one’s brain seems to move rapidly from one idea to another)</li>
<li>Distractibility</li>
<li>Psychomotor agitation, such as bouncing your leg or tapping your fingers, or an inability to sit still</li>
<li>With hypomania, an individual may not have problems in their social or work life. This condition typically does not result in hospitalization. Someone experiencing Hypomania might feel elated, and have an increased appetite or sex drive. But, he or she would likely still be able to go to work and manage ordinary tasks without many, if any, negative consequences.</li>
<li>Someone in a Hypomanic episode can usually complete work tasks. He or she should also have appropriate (though perhaps intense) interactions with coworkers. With full mania, regular tasks at work would be difficult to complete without making errors in judgment. Likewise, inappropriate social interactions might lead to negative consequences. Delusions and hallucinations are also not present in Hypomania.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_72153493a0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_72153493a0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand mixed features.</b> In some cases, people experience mania and depression at the same time. These individuals experience depression and irritability, racing thoughts, anxiety, and insomnia simultaneously.

<ul>
<li>Mania and Hypomania can qualify as having mixed features if there are also three or more symptoms of depression.</li>
<li>For example, imagine someone is engaging in risky behaviors. He or she is also experiencing insomnia, hyperactivity, and racing thoughts. This satisfies the full criteria for mania. If this person also experiences at least three symptoms of depression, this is a manic episode with mixed features. Example might be feelings of worthlessness, loss of interest in hobbies or activities, and recurrent thoughts of death.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Understanding_Different_Forms_of_Bipolar_Disorder_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Understanding_Different_Forms_of_Bipolar_Disorder">Understanding Different Forms of Bipolar Disorder</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_0e960af51a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0e960af51a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know the characteristics of bipolar disorder.</b> This form of bipolar disorder is the most commonly known manic-depressive form of the illness. A person classified as bipolar I must experience at least one manic episode or mixed episode. People with bipolar I disorder may also experience a depressive episode.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>People with bipolar I are the most likely to experience highs that lead to risky behavior.</li>
<li>This form of the illness is often disruptive to one's work life and relationships.</li>
<li>Those affected by Bipolar I are more likely to attempt suicide, with a completed suicide rate of 10-15%.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>People suffering from bipolar I are also at a high risk of having or developing a substance abuse problem.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>There is also a connection between bipolar I and hyperthyroidism. This makes it even more important to see a doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_d3e296298a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d3e296298a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand the symptoms of bipolar II disorder.</b> This variation involves less intense manic episodes and full-blown depressive episodes. The person may sometimes experience a muted version of hypomania. But, the underlying state is usually depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>People with bipolar II disorder are often misdiagnosed as having depression. To tell the difference, one must look for the distinguishing characteristics of bipolar depression.</li>
<li>Bipolar depression is different from MDD because it is often paired with manic symptoms. Sometimes there is overlap between the two. It takes a qualified professional to distinguish between these conditions.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>For people with bipolar II, mania may manifest as anxiety, irritability, or racing thoughts. Bursts of creativity and activity are less common.</li>
<li>Like bipolar I, there is a high risk for suicide, hyperthyroidism, and substance abuse in bipolar II.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Bipolar II tends to be more common in women than men.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e916f7eab9" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e916f7eab9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look for the signs of cyclothymia.</b> This is a milder form of bipolar disorder that involves mood swings with less severe instances of mania and depression. The mood swings tend to operate on a cycle, going back and forth between depression and mania. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM):<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Cyclothymia begins early in life and it’s onset is usually in adolescence and early adulthood.</li>
<li>Cyclothymia is equally common in men and women.</li>
<li>As with bipolar I and II, there is an increased risk of substance abuse for those affected by cyclothymia.</li>
<li>Sleep disorders are also commonly found alongside cyclothymia.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Know_How_to_Spot_Bipolar_Disorder_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Know_How_to_Spot_Bipolar_Disorder">Know How to Spot Bipolar Disorder</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e4d93fd351" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e4d93fd351')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/36/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look for seasonal changes in mood.</b> It's common for people with bipolar disorder to experience a shift as the seasons change. In some cases, a manic or depressive episode will last an entire season. In other cases, the change in season prompts the beginning of a cycle that includes both mania and depression.

<ul>
<li>Manic episodes are more common in the summertime. Depressive episodes are more common in the fall, winter and spring. This is not a hard and fast rule, however; some people experience depression in the summer and mania in the winter.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_60de4248e1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_60de4248e1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Understand that having bipolar disorder doesn't always impair functionality.</b> Some people with bipolar disorder have trouble at work and in school. In other cases, the person may seem to be doing just fine in these areas.

<ul>
<li>Those with bipolar II and cyclothymia can often function at work and school. Those with bipolar I tend to have a harder time in these areas.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 24" class="reference" id="_ref-24"><a href="#_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a6de0eedc2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a6de0eedc2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be aware of substance abuse issues.</b> Up to 50 percent of people who suffer from bipolar disorder struggle with substance abuse. They use alcohol or other tranquilizers to stop racing thoughts during manic episodes. They may also use drugs to try to achieve a high when they're in a depressive episode.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 25" class="reference" id="_ref-25"><a href="#_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Substances like alcohol have their own effects on mood and behavior. They can be difficult to distinguish bipolar disorder.</li>
<li>People who abuse drugs and alcohol are at greater risk of suicide. This is because substance abuse can increase the severity of both mania and depression.</li>
<li>Substance abuse may also instigate a cycle of manic depression.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_8263660fa4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8263660fa4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Notice breaks from reality.</b> People with bipolar disorder are often out of touch with reality. This occurs both during periods of extreme mania and periods of severe depression.

<ul>
<li>This can manifest as either a dangerously inflated ego or a sense of guilt that is not in proportion to real events. In some cases, psychosis and hallucinations occur.</li>
<li>Breaks from reality happen most frequently in bipolar I during manic and mixed episodes. They occur less often in bipolar II and almost never in cyclothymia.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 26" class="reference" id="_ref-26"><a href="#_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=700317" href="#/Image:Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-12.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_21fdbca7cd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_21fdbca7cd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-12.jpg/aid700317-v4-728px-Know-if-You-Have-Bipolar-Disorder-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See a specialist.</b> Self-diagnosis is useful if it leads to taking the next step toward getting help. Many people live with bipolar disorder without receiving treatment. But, the illness can be better managed with helpful medications. Psychotherapy with a psychiatrist or counselor can also make a big difference.

<ul>
<li>Medications used to treat Bipolar Disorder include mood stabilizers, anti-depressants, anti-psychotic, and anti-anxiety drugs. These medications work by blocking and/or regulating certain chemicals in the brain. They regulate Dopamine, Serotonin, and Acetylcholine.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 27" class="reference" id="_ref-27"><a href="#_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Mood stabilizers work to regulate a person’s mood. They prevent the extreme highs and lows of bipolar disorder. Among these are drugs such as Lithium, Depakote, Neurontin, Lamictal, and Topamax.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 28" class="reference" id="_ref-28"><a href="#_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Antipsychotic medications help reduce psychotic symptoms like hallucinations or delusions during mania. They include Zyprexa, Risperdal, Abilify and Saphris.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 29" class="reference" id="_ref-29"><a href="#_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Anti-depressant medications used to treat Bipolar depression include Lexapro, Zoloft, Prozac, and others. Finally, to manage symptoms of anxiety, a psychiatrist might prescribe Xanax, Klonopin, or Lorazepam.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 30" class="reference" id="_ref-30"><a href="#_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Medications should always be prescribed by a qualified psychiatrist or physician. They should be taken as directed to avoid health complications.</li>
<li>If you're concerned that you or a loved one has bipolar disorder, reach out to a therapist or psychiatrist for diagnosis.</li>
<li>If you or a loved one is having suicidal thoughts, immediately contact a trusted loved one or friend. Call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-8255 for more advice.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 31" class="reference" id="_ref-31"><a href="#_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="700317" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="147211" data-caid="148084" data-cqid="147228" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="838823" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="46">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I am 12 and a female and I don't know if I'm bipolar or just have mood swings. One day I would be feeling fine, and then something hits me and I want to be dead for several days, sometimes weeks, straight. I have anger issues and very bad anxiety. Is all this normal?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">No, it's not normal. Mood swings are normal to a degree, especially at your age, but what you describe sounds more serious than just mood swings. Perhaps it's bipolar disorder, perhaps it's something else. It would be best to see a psychologist to figure out what is wrong and get it sorted out. Try to explain the problem to your parents and ask them to help you.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>46</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="152105" data-caid="152978" data-cqid="152122" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="771576" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="17">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I tell my parents I think I am bipolar?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Ask them to set aside a time to talk without any distractions. Tell them that you're very depressed and you need to talk to your doctor about seeing a mental health professional. Leave it at that. You don't have to go into the specific diagnosis you suspect, wait until you've talked it over with a doctor and/or therapist and go from there.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>17</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="74197" data-caid="75070" data-cqid="74214" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="365471" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="12">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Are bipolar people more inclined to use crystal meth?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Medical case studies suggest individuals with mental or emotional illness such as depression, bipolar disorder, severe anxiety or borderline personality disorders are statistically more likely to abuse drugs in general, including crystal meth, cocaine, and heroin. However, people from all health levels, lifestyles, backgrounds or socioeconomic statuses are at risk of becoming involved with drugs.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>12</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="299595" data-caid="300468" data-cqid="299612" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1421879" data-submitter_id="4193072" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="7">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My mom would be upset if I told her after I was getting better that I got depressed again and now I'm even more depressed. What should I do?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-Fw9Ac3fiagg/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAANw/ADGQefbh5B0/s96-c/photo.jpg)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Leah-Currie">Leah Currie</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If you're not comfortable talking to your parents, call a free helpline. The therapists give really good advice, and they are good to talk to.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>7</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="63781" data-caid="64654" data-cqid="63798" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="433758" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="4" data-votes_up="22">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Does changing moods count? Like, sometimes I'm energetic, and then in a couple of minutes, I feel bored and lifeless without knowing the reason. </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Changing moods doesn't automatically mean you are bipolar. But if you're seriously concerned about it, consult a mental health clinic.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="317029" data-caid="317902" data-cqid="317046" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1357027" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="9">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="392387" data-caid="393260" data-cqid="392404" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1276149" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="4">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is it normal for a teenager to range between really happy and excited to depressed, or should I see a psychiatrist?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">What you're describing as absolutely normal and a result of the increase in hormones during puberty. However, if your mood swings are really severe and getting in the way of your daily life, bring this up with your parents and suggest they take you to your doctor just to talk it over.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="180272" data-caid="181145" data-cqid="180289" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="843182" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="6">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I can't tell if I am bipolar. My extreme moods make it hard to keep relationships. How do I know if I am, or if I am just moody?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If you are concerned about your mental health, you should go see a doctor and/or psychiatrist. If you have mood swings in combination with relationship problem, you might have borderline personality disorder. I'd suggest you research both borderline and different bipolar disorders (including cyclothymia) and see if any seems to fit. No matter what, if you are concerned, go see a professional. They can help you further.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>6</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="315342" data-caid="316215" data-cqid="315359" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1603117" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How can I tell if I have bipolar disorder or just mood swings?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You can talk to a trained professional about it. Ask your parent or another trusted adult to set up an appointment for you with a psychologist or psychiatrist, and they will be able to diagnose you based on the behaviors that you are exhibiting. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="97643" data-caid="98516" data-cqid="97660" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="707098" data-submitter_id="3755449" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="7" data-votes_up="15">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I'm a 12 year old female, and I don't know if I'm bipolar. My moods seem to change a lot and I get irritated really easy and I get twitchy quite a bit. My "friend" is very abusive and rude to me. What do you think?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/skins/WikiHow/images/80x80_user.png)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Rachel-Stanford">Rachel Stanford</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">First off, you have to understand the difference between being bipolar and being moody. Being moody and irritable is pretty normal for people going through puberty. Day-to-day mood changes do not generally constitute bipolar disorder. Usually with bipolar disorder, you have an extended period of depression followed by a period of exceptionally high energy followed by another extended period of depression, and so on. If you want to know for sure whether there is something wrong with you, get diagnosed by a specialist. As for your 'friend' - you should end that friendship as soon as possible, as that is not how any friend should treat you. There is no need to keep such toxic people in your life, and if someone is being abusive to you, it's no wonder if you're anxious and irritable.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>7</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>15</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>

			{{#verifierId}}
				<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" target="_blank" {{#verifierData.imagePath}}style="background-image: url({{verifierData.imagePath}})"{{/verifierData.imagePath}}>
					{{^verifierData.imagePath}}<span>{{verifierData.initials}}</span>{{/verifierData.imagePath}}</a>
			{{/verifierId}}

			{{^verifierId}}
				<div class="qa_person_circle" {{#submitterAvatar}}style="background-image:url({{{submitterAvatar}}})"{{/submitterAvatar}}></div>
			{{/verifierId}}

				<div class="qa_answerer_info">
				{{#verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">
						<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" target="_blank">{{verifierData.name}}</a>
					</div>
					<div class="qa_user_title">{{{verifierData.blurb}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

				{{^verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">{{{submitterDisplayName}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

					<div class="qa_user_label">{{qa_answerer_label}}</div>
					{{#isTopAnswerer}}{{^qa_desktop}}<div class="qa_ta_mobile_extra"></div>{{/qa_desktop}}{{/isTopAnswerer}}
				</div>
			</div>

		{{#qa_desktop}}
			<div class="qa_answer answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</div>
			<div class="qa_answer_footer">
				{{> thumbs_qa_widget}}
				{{^qa_anon}}
				<a class="qa_ignore_answered" href="#">{{qa_flag_duplicate}}</a>
				<p class="qa_ignore_answered_thanks">Thanks!</p>
				{{/qa_anon}}
			</div>
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		{{^qa_desktop}}
		<ul>
			<li class="qa_answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</li>
		</ul>
		{{> thumbs_up_down}}
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

		</script><!-- Template for rendering an unpatrolled QA --><!--  Template form for desktop thumbs up/down functionality  --><script id="qa_thumbs_qa_widget" type="text/x-handlebars-template">

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Keep a calendar. Marking the beginning and end of "Manic" and "depressive" episodes can give you a tactile resource that can help predict episodes. Note that no one can predict the beginnings of an episode perfectly.</li>
<li>If you are a heavy drinker or you use drugs, these can both cause mood swings with the appearance of bipolar disorder. Abstaining from these substances may help.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>This article is only intended to help you look for possible symptoms of bipolar disorder. It is not meant to diagnose or treat. Please see a doctor if you think you or a loved one may have bipolar disorder.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>If you think you have bipolar disorder, check to see if you exhibit common symptoms, like having moods that alternate between extreme high periods, also known as mania, and depression. You may also experience manic episodes, which include feelings like euphoria, racing thoughts, and engaging in reckless behavior, while depressive periods involve feelings of hopelessness and guilt. If you think you may be bipolar, make an appointment with a mental health specialist to start a treatment plan, which may include therapy and/or medication. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For more advice from our Mental Health reviewer, including how to recognize and diagnose the different types of bipolar disorder, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    },
    "author": {

            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",

    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Trudi Griffin, LPC"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Identifying the Symptoms",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Recognize the signs of mania. During a manic period, feelings of euphoria, creativity, and heightened awareness are common.[4] Manic periods may last a few hours or stretch on for days or weeks.[5] The Mayo Clinic describes the following signs of mania:[6]\nHaving a feeling of being \"high,\" so high, in some cases, that one feels invincible. This is often accompanied by the feeling that one has special powers or is godlike.\nDealing with racing thoughts. Thoughts may jump from subject to subject so quickly that it's difficult to keep up or concentrate on one thing.\nTalking so quickly that others can't make sense of what one is saying, and feeling jumpy and restless.\nStaying up all night or sleeping for only a few hours at a time, but never feeling tired the next day.\nExhibiting reckless behavior. During a manic episode, a person might sleep with several people and not use protection. He or she may gamble large amounts of money or make risky business investments. An individual might also spend money on large, expensive items, quit a job, and so on.\nExhibiting extreme irritability and impatience with others. This can escalate into starting arguments and picking fights with people who don't go along with one's ideas.\nIn rare cases, delusions, hallucinations, and visions can occur (e.g. believing to hear the voice of God or an angel)."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Know the symptoms of bipolar depression. For those with bipolar disorder, the periods of depression are longer and more frequent than periods of mania. Watch for these symptoms:[7]\nAn inability to experience pleasure, joy even happiness.\nFeelings of hopelessness and inadequacy. Feelings of worthlessness and guilt are also common.\nSleeping more than normal and feeling tired and sluggish all the time.\nGaining weight and having changes in appetite.\nExperiencing thoughts of death and suicide.\nNote that bipolar depression often looks a lot like Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). A qualified professional can differentiate between the two disorders. He or she will look at the patient\u2019s history of mania and severity of manic episodes.[8]\nThe medication used to treat MDD is often not effective for treating bipolar depression. It also is often accompanied by irritability and mood swings that aren't exhibited by those with MDD.[9]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Understand the signs of a Hypomanic Episode. A Hypomanic Episode is an abnormally and persistently elevated mood that lasts for four days. It can also include irritability and other symptoms.[10]Hypomania is different from a manic episode because it is usually less severe. Watch out for:[11]\nFeelings of Elation\nIrritability\nInflated self-esteem or grandiosity\nDecreased need for sleep\nPressured speech (speech that is rapid and intense)\nFlight of ideas (when one\u2019s brain seems to move rapidly from one idea to another)\nDistractibility\nPsychomotor agitation, such as bouncing your leg or tapping your fingers, or an inability to sit still\nWith hypomania, an individual may not have problems in their social or work life. This condition typically does not result in hospitalization. Someone experiencing Hypomania might feel elated, and have an increased appetite or sex drive. But, he or she would likely still be able to go to work and manage ordinary tasks without many, if any, negative consequences.\nSomeone in a Hypomanic episode can usually complete work tasks. He or she should also have appropriate (though perhaps intense) interactions with coworkers. With full mania, regular tasks at work would be difficult to complete without making errors in judgment. Likewise, inappropriate social interactions might lead to negative consequences. Delusions and hallucinations are also not present in Hypomania.[12]"

title: How to Know if You Have Bipolar Disorder
content_html:
Recognize the signs of mania. During a manic period, feelings of euphoria, creativity, and heightened awareness are common.[4] Manic periods may last a few hours or stretch on for days or weeks.[5] The Mayo Clinic describes the following signs of mania:[6]
  • Having a feeling of being "high," so high, in some cases, that one feels invincible. This is often accompanied by the feeling that one has special powers or is godlike.
  • Dealing with racing thoughts. Thoughts may jump from subject to subject so quickly that it's difficult to keep up or concentrate on one thing.
  • Talking so quickly that others can't make sense of what one is saying, and feeling jumpy and restless.
  • Staying up all night or sleeping for only a few hours at a time, but never feeling tired the next day.
  • Exhibiting reckless behavior. During a manic episode, a person might sleep with several people and not use protection. He or she may gamble large amounts of money or make risky business investments. An individual might also spend money on large, expensive items, quit a job, and so on.
  • Exhibiting extreme irritability and impatience with others. This can escalate into starting arguments and picking fights with people who don't go along with one's ideas.
  • In rare cases, delusions, hallucinations, and visions can occur (e.g. believing to hear the voice of God or an angel).
Know the symptoms of bipolar depression. For those with bipolar disorder, the periods of depression are longer and more frequent than periods of mania. Watch for these symptoms:[7]
  • An inability to experience pleasure, joy even happiness.
  • Feelings of hopelessness and inadequacy. Feelings of worthlessness and guilt are also common.
  • Sleeping more than normal and feeling tired and sluggish all the time.
  • Gaining weight and having changes in appetite.
  • Experiencing thoughts of death and suicide.
  • Note that bipolar depression often looks a lot like Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). A qualified professional can differentiate between the two disorders. He or she will look at the patient’s history of mania and severity of manic episodes.[8]
  • The medication used to treat MDD is often not effective for treating bipolar depression. It also is often accompanied by irritability and mood swings that aren't exhibited by those with MDD.[9]
Understand the signs of a Hypomanic Episode. A Hypomanic Episode is an abnormally and persistently elevated mood that lasts for four days. It can also include irritability and other symptoms.[10]Hypomania is different from a manic episode because it is usually less severe. Watch out for:[11]
  • Feelings of Elation
  • Irritability
  • Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
  • Decreased need for sleep
  • Pressured speech (speech that is rapid and intense)
  • Flight of ideas (when one’s brain seems to move rapidly from one idea to another)
  • Distractibility
  • Psychomotor agitation, such as bouncing your leg or tapping your fingers, or an inability to sit still
  • With hypomania, an individual may not have problems in their social or work life. This condition typically does not result in hospitalization. Someone experiencing Hypomania might feel elated, and have an increased appetite or sex drive. But, he or she would likely still be able to go to work and manage ordinary tasks without many, if any, negative consequences.
  • Someone in a Hypomanic episode can usually complete work tasks. He or she should also have appropriate (though perhaps intense) interactions with coworkers. With full mania, regular tasks at work would be difficult to complete without making errors in judgment. Likewise, inappropriate social interactions might lead to negative consequences. Delusions and hallucinations are also not present in Hypomania.[12]
Understand mixed features. In some cases, people experience mania and depression at the same time. These individuals experience depression and irritability, racing thoughts, anxiety, and insomnia simultaneously.
  • Mania and Hypomania can qualify as having mixed features if there are also three or more symptoms of depression.
  • For example, imagine someone is engaging in risky behaviors. He or she is also experiencing insomnia, hyperactivity, and racing thoughts. This satisfies the full criteria for mania. If this person also experiences at least three symptoms of depression, this is a manic episode with mixed features. Example might be feelings of worthlessness, loss of interest in hobbies or activities, and recurrent thoughts of death.[13]
Know the characteristics of bipolar disorder. This form of bipolar disorder is the most commonly known manic-depressive form of the illness. A person classified as bipolar I must experience at least one manic episode or mixed episode. People with bipolar I disorder may also experience a depressive episode.[14]
  • People with bipolar I are the most likely to experience highs that lead to risky behavior.
  • This form of the illness is often disruptive to one's work life and relationships.
  • Those affected by Bipolar I are more likely to attempt suicide, with a completed suicide rate of 10-15%.[15]
  • People suffering from bipolar I are also at a high risk of having or developing a substance abuse problem.[16]
  • There is also a connection between bipolar I and hyperthyroidism. This makes it even more important to see a doctor.[17]
Understand the symptoms of bipolar II disorder. This variation involves less intense manic episodes and full-blown depressive episodes. The person may sometimes experience a muted version of hypomania. But, the underlying state is usually depression.[18]
  • People with bipolar II disorder are often misdiagnosed as having depression. To tell the difference, one must look for the distinguishing characteristics of bipolar depression.
  • Bipolar depression is different from MDD because it is often paired with manic symptoms. Sometimes there is overlap between the two. It takes a qualified professional to distinguish between these conditions.[19]
  • For people with bipolar II, mania may manifest as anxiety, irritability, or racing thoughts. Bursts of creativity and activity are less common.
  • Like bipolar I, there is a high risk for suicide, hyperthyroidism, and substance abuse in bipolar II.[20]
  • Bipolar II tends to be more common in women than men.[21]
Look for the signs of cyclothymia. This is a milder form of bipolar disorder that involves mood swings with less severe instances of mania and depression. The mood swings tend to operate on a cycle, going back and forth between depression and mania. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM):[22]
  • Cyclothymia begins early in life and it’s onset is usually in adolescence and early adulthood.
  • Cyclothymia is equally common in men and women.
  • As with bipolar I and II, there is an increased risk of substance abuse for those affected by cyclothymia.
  • Sleep disorders are also commonly found alongside cyclothymia.
Look for seasonal changes in mood. It's common for people with bipolar disorder to experience a shift as the seasons change. In some cases, a manic or depressive episode will last an entire season. In other cases, the change in season prompts the beginning of a cycle that includes both mania and depression.
  • Manic episodes are more common in the summertime. Depressive episodes are more common in the fall, winter and spring. This is not a hard and fast rule, however; some people experience depression in the summer and mania in the winter.[23]
Understand that having bipolar disorder doesn't always impair functionality. Some people with bipolar disorder have trouble at work and in school. In other cases, the person may seem to be doing just fine in these areas.
  • Those with bipolar II and cyclothymia can often function at work and school. Those with bipolar I tend to have a harder time in these areas.[24]
Be aware of substance abuse issues. Up to 50 percent of people who suffer from bipolar disorder struggle with substance abuse. They use alcohol or other tranquilizers to stop racing thoughts during manic episodes. They may also use drugs to try to achieve a high when they're in a depressive episode.[25]
  • Substances like alcohol have their own effects on mood and behavior. They can be difficult to distinguish bipolar disorder.
  • People who abuse drugs and alcohol are at greater risk of suicide. This is because substance abuse can increase the severity of both mania and depression.
  • Substance abuse may also instigate a cycle of manic depression.
Notice breaks from reality. People with bipolar disorder are often out of touch with reality. This occurs both during periods of extreme mania and periods of severe depression.
  • This can manifest as either a dangerously inflated ego or a sense of guilt that is not in proportion to real events. In some cases, psychosis and hallucinations occur.
  • Breaks from reality happen most frequently in bipolar I during manic and mixed episodes. They occur less often in bipolar II and almost never in cyclothymia.[26]
See a specialist. Self-diagnosis is useful if it leads to taking the next step toward getting help. Many people live with bipolar disorder without receiving treatment. But, the illness can be better managed with helpful medications. Psychotherapy with a psychiatrist or counselor can also make a big difference.
  • Medications used to treat Bipolar Disorder include mood stabilizers, anti-depressants, anti-psychotic, and anti-anxiety drugs. These medications work by blocking and/or regulating certain chemicals in the brain. They regulate Dopamine, Serotonin, and Acetylcholine.[27]
  • Mood stabilizers work to regulate a person’s mood. They prevent the extreme highs and lows of bipolar disorder. Among these are drugs such as Lithium, Depakote, Neurontin, Lamictal, and Topamax.[28]
  • Antipsychotic medications help reduce psychotic symptoms like hallucinations or delusions during mania. They include Zyprexa, Risperdal, Abilify and Saphris.[29]
  • Anti-depressant medications used to treat Bipolar depression include Lexapro, Zoloft, Prozac, and others. Finally, to manage symptoms of anxiety, a psychiatrist might prescribe Xanax, Klonopin, or Lorazepam.[30]
  • Medications should always be prescribed by a qualified psychiatrist or physician. They should be taken as directed to avoid health complications.
  • If you're concerned that you or a loved one has bipolar disorder, reach out to a therapist or psychiatrist for diagnosis.
  • If you or a loved one is having suicidal thoughts, immediately contact a trusted loved one or friend. Call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-8255 for more advice.[31]
